awd_titl_txt: Synthesis of Glycogen in Bacteria and Starch in Plants: Evolution and Mechanism of Allosteric Control
awd_abstract_narration:
ADP-glucose pyrophosphorylase is central to starch synthesis in plants and glycogen synthesis in bacteria and other organisms, serving as carbon storage polymers. It is a common biotechnology target and an informed understanding of its regulation has implications for starch/glycogen synthesis in a host of organisms.  Allosteric control of ADP-glucose pyrophosphorylase activity is an important but poorly understood regulatory mechanism.  Presently it is unclear how the enzyme is allosterically activated and how that activation signal is transmitted structurally within the enzyme. The goal of this project is to perform computational, structural and biochemical studies to understand and characterize the allosteric signals and the interaction of the allosteric effectors on ADP-glucose pyrophosphorylase activity in bacteria as a model for plants.  The PIs predict the presence of a common structural element that works as a switch but also the presence of an alternative allosteric signal binding site. This project will also contribute to education by training undergraduate and graduate students, establish international collaborations, and foster participation of underrepresented minorities in research by supporting programs such as McNair-SROP.  This project will also support an international course on protein science that includes elements of the research, providing a unique training opportunity for undergraduate and graduate students.  

Plant starch and bacterial glycogen biosynthetic pathways provide models for the structure and evolution of allosteric regulatory functions of the enzyme ADP-glucose pyrophosphorylase. Despite the importance of these pathways, the allosteric mechanism that controls the activity of this enzyme is largely unknown. The project comprises computational, structural, and biochemical studies to understand and characterize the transmission of the allosteric signal and the interaction of the allosteric effectors in the ADP-glucose pyrophosphorylase family.  It is predicted there is both a common structural element that works as a switch and an alternative allosteric signal guided by a secondary site. Three main research objectives will be pursued: 1) screen several enzyme forms from diverse branches of the phylogenetic tree for the presence of a dual allosteric mechanism; 2) obtain crystal structures of allosteric mutants ("switched off") in several different conditions with different ligands to test the hypothesis that certain residues form a conserved allosteric switch in ADP-glucose pyrophosphorylases; and 3) perform computational studies (molecular dynamics, correlated movement analysis, and network pathway analysis) to predict the signaling pathways of activation from each putative allosteric site.

Intellectual Merits Goals

The ADP-glucose pyrophosphorylase enzyme has been studied in different species, including bacteria and plants to understand how its regulation has evolved. This is critical to understand how evolution has shaped the control of bacterial glycogen and starch production in plants since this enzyme is responsible for it. We found a very diverse set of activators in species that have not been explored before. For instance, a newly discovered branch of cyanobacteria (Melainabacteria) was mainly activated by glucose 6-phosphate, which made it different from the known photosynthetic cyanobacteria.  In addition, we found that bacterial ADP-glucose pyrophosphorylase from Firmicutes are mostly activated by a variety of phosphorylated sugars in contrast with the previous notion that this branch may have been unregulated.

One of the unexpected findings was that the regulation of this enzyme not only control its activity, but also the type of product it generates by selecting different substrates. In this way, the activators can make the enzyme change what type of metabolites produce, consequently controlling metabolism. We found that this might have tremendous implications for how metabolic control can evolve. In certain cases, this specificity can be evolved by an original interaction with a regulator that later by mutations. This knowledge could be used for creating biotechnological tools to produce compounds of biochemical interest.

The diversity in regulation is determined by structure. By X-ray crystallography, we found two distinct sites where the activators bind in the Agrobacterium tumefaciens enzyme (one for sugar-phosphates and one for pyruvate) and they interact synergistically. The complexity of this interaction forced us to upgrade the theory of previous models that described enzyme activation. The fact that there are two sites, it expands the landscape that evolution explores to enhance regulatory diversity. This two-site model can now be applied to other enzymes from different species. For instance, we were able to map properly the activation sites in the Escherichia coli enzyme.

In plants, enzymes are formed by two different subunits (“small” and “large”). We found that the interaction between these subunits is critical for regulation. We observed in wheat that the “large” subunit is responsible for “pre-activating” the enzyme. This creates a scenario where the enzyme is regulated by phosphate inhibition of that pre-activated form. We also found in Ostreococcus tauri (unicellular algae) how certain mutations led to the loss of the ability of the large subunit to bind efficiently the activator. We proved it by resurrecting these properties with mutagenesis.

It has been described that the interaction with metabolites (allosteric activation) regulates the activity of the ADP-glucose pyrophosphorylase. Reduction (an indirect effect of photosynthesis) also contributes to the regulation. Here, we found that the enzyme from wheat is also regulated by phosphorylation. This breakthrough will allow a future deeper understanding of how starch is controlled in cereals.

In addition to all these findings, we developed a method to quantify the ability of activators or any other compound to bind proteins, using a previously described phenomenon. Proteins are stabilized when they are in presence of such ligand, and the stabilization is detected by an increase of the temperature needed to “melt” the protein. We develop the theory to calculate the binding constants.

Broader Impacts Goals

The educational impact was very significant at the graduate and undergraduate level. We trained five undergraduate students to perform research and related aspects such as writing papers, preparing posters, and presenting them in conferences. This is critical for their career since it is important whether they go to areas of health science (e.g. Medical School) or Biochemistry (graduate school). Seven PhD students at different stages of their career contributed to the project and benefit from them. Five of them already graduated.

The international collaboration had a great influence not only on the personnel overseas but also in our University. We hosted an Argentine post-doc and provided this visiting scholar an opportunity to establish networks with our University. We welcome three short-term PhD student visitors from Argentina. This continued to strengthen our network with our international collaborators. Two of them were funded by Fulbright Scholarship. In all cases, we trained them to mentor undergraduate students, which was a rewarding synergistic activity for these international scientists and our students.

Students from high-school benefit from the “Emerging Scientist Workshop” organized in our Department and we contributed to it. Another program we contributed was the FYRE (First Year Research Experience). This allowed first year students to experience research over the summer and make decisions on their career. Our projects also had a major impact on senior students in our Biochemistry Major. We developed a course, based on the ADP-glucose pyrophosphorylase enzyme to expose them to an “undergraduate research experience”
